CloudMagic vs. Acompli vs. Boxer: Battling for the Crown

May 19, 2014
13 minute read

Let’s get something straight here: despite a graphical overhaul in iOS 7, Apple’s Mail for iOS has remained largely the same since its inception…and that’s not a good thing.

Today’s users need an email client that does more than just send email. It needs to support a variety of account types; it needs to support 3rd party service integrations; it needs to handle file and invite management; and so much more.

Recently, I started experimenting with three relatively new entrants to the iOS mail app market: CloudMagic, Acompli, and Boxer. All three outperform Mail is many key areas, and it occurred to me that a product comparison might be in order.

TL;DR

It’s time to find an alternative to Apple Mail on iOS; here are three worthy conteders.

The Background

This guide is not intended to be the end-all, be-all guide to these three applications. As such, I do not cover every single aspect of their functionality. Rather, I focus on those aspects that are, I feel, crucial to a better mobile email experience. You should research each app as much as possible to see if it meets your needs.

Furthermore, I try to not blend categories together. For instance, whether an app implements multiple device versions should not affect the verdict on its UI.

The Entrants

Let’s meet the contestants and learn a little about them.

 CloudMagic

CloudMagic is a mail app that focuses on several key virtues:

  • Multiple email services in one app
  • Inline access to several popular 3rd party apps
  • Simple GTD concepts

CloudMagic has gotten tremendous press thus far:

The best Android and iPhone mobile email app. – WSJ

The email application that lets you complete your work right from your Inbox. – TechCrunch

 Acompli

Acompli focuses on tasks and workflows for busy professionals:

  • Share calendar availability via email
  • Manage attachments with ease
  • Manage contacts with ease

Currently, Acompli is getting a lot of press for having recently secured $7.3 million in funding.

 Boxer

Boxer focuses on adding GTD principles and social features to the email experience:

  • Tasks
  • Assignees
  • Email Likes

Boxer has been around some time and is often referenced as one of the first apps to seriously challenge iOS Mail.

Breakdown

If you’re in a hurry, here is a tabular breakdown of the (as I see it) major needs of a mobile email client and whether each of our contestants meets it.

✕ – employs this feature to great effect
✕ – employs this feature to decent effect
✕ – does not use this feature

User Interface

CloudMagic

CloudMagic features a beautiful interface. Muted colors, great gestures, excellent iconography…it all works.

Interactions occur primarily via gestures and nicely hidden menus. No UI element gets in the way of interaction; nothing feels like it hinders the overall experience. That simplicity of experience is a huge relief.

CloudMagic’s UI comes closest to the fine UIs developed in email apps such as Mailbox and Sparrow. Navigating around CloudMagic is a joy; it’s as simple as that.

Acompli

Acompli’s UI is very well done, if a bit “iOS 7-boilerplate-esque.”

Acompli’s “functional groups” are accessible via the standard iOS bottom-of-the-app navigational links. Within each group, the UI changes to accommodate the desired experience (e.g., the “Calendar” UI closely mimics a calendar app).

Although the Acompli UI has gestures, they are often eschewed in favor of the traditional tap-based gestures. This makes for a recognizable (and thus, easy to learn) UI, if one that is a little uninspired.

Boxer

Boxer’s UI has come a long way since its inception. It closely mimics CloudMagic in terms of a slidable left-hand menu, simple buttons, and a gesture-based interface.

The Boxer UI’s killer feature is its ability to customize gestures. Users can define what short/long left/right swipes look like for an email; for instance, one might choose the following setup:

  • Short left swipe: Mark as Spam
  • Long left swipe: Send to Evernote
  • Short right swipe: Archive
  • Long right swipe: Delete

Although the basic interactions of Boxer’s UI are similar to CloudMagic, the overall feeling is slightly clunkier. Buttons are bigger than (I think) necessary, windows and panels contrast rather starkly, and the app’s color scheme is a bit jarring. That said, the overall experience is still solid.

VERDICT: CloudMagic

In terms of a purely usable UI that is intuitive, original, and easy on the eyes, CloudMagic wins.

Multiple Account Types

CloudMagic

CloudMagic supports a large list of email services:

  • Email for Google Apps
  • Gmail
  • Microsoft Outlook 365
  • Microsoft Exchange
  • Microsoft Outlook.com
  • Yahoo! Mail
  • iCloud
  • IMAP

It’s important to note that CloudMagic limits users to 5 accounts.1

Acompli

Acompli, in its own words, chooses to focus on the most popular email services:

  • Microsoft Exchange
  • Microsoft Outlook.com
  • Email for Google Apps
  • Gmail
  • Windows Live Hotmail

Boxer

  • Microsoft Exchange
  • Microsoft Outlook.com
  • Email for Google Apps
  • Gmail
  • Yahoo! Mail
  • iCloud
  • AOL
  • IMAP

VERDICT: Tie (CloudMagic and Boxer)

Although all three apps support a number of services, CloudMagic and Boxer support the largest number. Acompli’s want to focus on the most used services is completely valid, but a larger number of services tends to attract a larger number of users.

Contact Management

CloudMagic

Other than connecting to iOS’ built-in contact manager, CloudMagic does not carry any special contact management abilities.

Acompli

Although it’s not a radical shift, Acompli implements a very useful feature: recent contacts. This allows users to quickly send emails to contacts who have already been recently emailed.

Boxer

Boxer implements its own contact list manager and blends LinkedIn and Facebook information into those contacts. Beyond that, however, contact management is as you would expect.

VERDICT: Acompli

Although it isn’t the most noted feature, Acompli’s inclusion of any unique functionality (unfortunately, the contact enhancements of Boxer don’t offer much tactical value) here elevates it as the winner.

File Attachments

CloudMagic

CloudMagic’s file management abilities are limited to attaching photos to an email. Although this is a step above the iOS Mail app, it’s not quite enough to crown CloudMagic’s file management functionality as truly next-generation.

Acompli

Acompli’s file management capabilities are robust. In addition to being able to attach photos to an email, Acompli also allows users to pick from a file library (composed of files that exist in any email across the user’s accounts):

This is a feature I’ve yet to run across before and it becomes incredibly useful. The one drawback is that it forces you to keep your files-for-email in your email (which might not be for the best).

Boxer

Boxer, too, has robust file management capabilities. Like Acompli, Boxer allows users to take attach photos to emails (via the library or via a direct camera shot) and attach files; unlike Acompli, Boxer chooses to connect to a user’s Dropbox or Box.com account and attach files from there:

Upon selecting a file, Boxer generates a link to the file and places it in the email draft.

VERDICT: Boxer

Acompli comes close, but Boxer’s ability to include files in 3rd party file management solutions like Dropbox takes the cake.

Calendar Management

CloudMagic

CloudMagic’s ability to manage calendar invites is questionable (usually depending on where the invite comes from). For instance, an invite from Google Calendar isn’t bad:

Fortunately, Google’s built-in acceptance links show up (allowing users to respond to the invite from the email). Invites from other services (such as Microsoft Exchange), however, are not nearly as good:

In both cases, users can touch on the .ics file and see event details, but nothing more.

When it comes to creating and mailing events natively, CloudMagic does not currently offer support.

Acompli

Acompli handles events much more gracefully; in both of my tests, Acompli recognizes that the email has an event and gives users the ability to accept or decline directly from the email:

When creating invites, Acompli allows users the ability to create them directly within the app (a greatly useful feature when once is used to creating events only in a calendar app). Even better, Acompli allows users to send available time slots within an email:

Boxer

Like CloudMagic, Boxer has very limited calendar management abilities. Most unfortunately, it often is unable to recognize (or do anything with) events sent from Microsoft Exchange (choosing instead to simply display an empty email body).

VERDICT: Acompli

It may not have everything, but Acompli handles calendar management far better than either CloudMagic or Boxer.

Robust Searching

CloudMagic

CloudMagic’s searching capabilities do exactly what’s expected. Of particular note: CloudMagic was consistently the fastest app to return search results.

Acompli

Acompli’s searching capabilities were neck and neck with the others in terms of speed and accuracy of results.

Boxer

Boxer’s searching capabilities were neck and neck with the others in terms of speed and accuracy of results.

VERDICT: Tie (CloudMagic, Acompli, and Boxer)

All three apps perform admirably here. Boxer seems to crash now and then while searching, but it’s sporadic and inconsistent enough to not detract.

Multiple Signatures

CloudMagic

CloudMagic offers the ability to include plain text signatures for each account.

Acompli

Acompli, too, offers the ability to include plain text signatures for each account.

Boxer

Boxer, too offers the ability to include plain text signatures for each account.

VERDICT: Tie (CloudMagic, Acompli, and Boxer)

All three apps offer this crucial functionality (with none outperforming the others).

Quick Reply Templates

CloudMagic

This functionality is not included in CloudMagic.

Acompli

This functionality is not included in Acomply.

Boxer

Boxer shines here by allowing users to use templates for quick email replies (such as, “Running a bit late.”):


Even more powerful, Boxer allows users to create their own templates.

VERDICT: Boxer

Boxer is the clear winner here by virtue of being the only app to include this functionality.

Batch Editing

CloudMagic

By long pressing on an email, CloudMagic activates a multi-select mode that allows users to touch-to-select multiple emails:

Once selected, emails can be moved to a folder (specific to that email’s account, of course), trashed, archived, or marked as read via a set of buttons at the top of the app.

Acompli

Acompli allows users to touch an edit link and multi-select emails, as well:

Once selected, emails can be flagged, marked as read, moved to a folder, trashed, and archived.

Boxer

Boxer allows emails to be multi-selected via touching on the user picture next to each:

Once selected, emails can have a bevy of actions performed upon them (including trashing, marking as spam, converting to todos, and more) via either left/right gestures or an actions menu in the upper right corner of the app.

VERDICT: Boxer

All apps do a great job at allowing users to multi-select emails. Boxer gets the nod here because it offers a great deal more actions to be performed on these selected emails.

Multiple Device Support

CloudMagic

CloudMagic is a universal app that supports both iPhone and iPad. There is an Android version, as well.

Acompli

Acompli now exists for the iPhone only (although, plans for an Android app are in the works2).

Boxer

Boxer exists as a universal app that supports both iPhone and iPad.

VERDICT: CloudMagic

By virtue of its already-existing device support lineup, CloudMagic wins this round.

3rd Party Integrations

CloudMagic

CloudMagic supports the ability to send emails to a bevy of 3rd party services (via “cards”):

  • Microsoft OneNote
  • Trello
  • Salesforce
  • Zendesk
  • Mailchimp
  • Evernote
  • Pocket
  • Sender Profile (a service that collects information about the sender)

Even more exciting, the CloudMagic teams promises that more cards are coming (and that a developer platform is being created to allow others to create their own cards).

Acompli

Acompli does not support any outside services (and doesn’t seem to reference any plans for future support).

Boxer

Boxer supports sending email to many services:

  • Box
  • Dropbox
  • Evernote
  • Sanebox

Additionally, Boxer can connect to various services to bring in information about email contacts:

  • Facebook
  • LinkedIn
  • Twitter

VERDICT: CloudMagic

It’s a neck-and-neck race between CloudMagic and Boxer; at this point, the promise of an independent service development platform puts CloudMagic slightly ahead.

GTD Focus

CloudMagic

Although CloudMagic doesn’t explicitly support GTD principles, its quick actions and “don’t-get-in-the-way” mentality support the principle of getting to zero inbox. CloudMagic does support adding iOS Reminders to emails, ensuring that users are always notified of needed emails.

CloudMagic even features a nice graphic (and some helpful advice) once you reach this point:

Acompli

Acompli features robust (if not direct) support for GTD. The inclusion of calendar and (minimal) contact management within the app ensures that users don’t have to wander around. Acompli also lets users attach iOS Reminders to emails.

Boxer

Boxer features the most direct support of GTD within the three apps. Emails can be converted into todos, assigned to other Boxer users, and given due dates/times. Boxer’s quick actions allow these conversions to happen effortlessly.

Like CloudMagic, Boxer gives some added GTD motivation (with the ability to share its results):

VERDICT: Boxer

Boxer’s direct focus on GTD makes it the winner here.

Undo Ability

CloudMagic

CloudMagic allows for users to undo most actions made to emails (like deletion, moving, etc.).

Acompli

Acompli, too, allows for users to undo most actions made to emails.

Boxer

Boxer, too, allows for users to undo most actions made to emails.

VERDICT: Tie (CloudMagic, Acompli, and Boxer)

With identical functionality in play, all three apps win this round.

The Champion

It’s been a long, trying contest. Let’s see how these apps stack up based on the number of rounds won (and assume that all rounds carry equal importance):

  • CloudMagic: 7
  • Acompli: 5
  • Boxer: 8

Which One Is Right For Me?

All three of these apps deserve a look; although they achieve different functionality with different results, they each fly above and beyond Apple’s default Mail offering.

For now, I’m using CloudMagic, simply because it’s 3rd party services are the ones I happen to use most often. That said, both Acompli and Boxer and sitting nearby, waiting for the next update that will push them above the rest.

An important note: CloudMagic and Acompli route your email through their servers before arriving on your device.34 There’s a multitude of reasons for this – better push notifications, etc. – but if you’re concerned about your information residing on some third party server, these apps might not be the ones for you. (EDIT: I had previously thought that this was the case with Boxer, too, but was corrected).

 

  • “We incur high costs, as we use the cloud to deliver emails to your device. Hence the restriction. Cloud enables us to make your email awesome and offer uniform experience across all your devices. Having said that, we are continually working on reducing our costs and in turn pass on the benefits to you.” ↩
